text:
Based on prior suggestions, I used beef broth instead of water, and only a 2.5 lb roast with the same amount of spices.  In the end, the flavors came out perfectly.  I served each sandwich on a toasted whole wheat roll and topped with onions, bell pepper, and mushrooms (sauteed in olive oil), a slice of provolone cheese, and this TO DIE FOR horseradish sauce I found on this site (Flank Steak with Horseradish Sauce submitted by Taste of Home's Light & Tasty...I HIGHLY recommend it! :).  Put em under the broiler for a few seconds and served.  I thought this made some pretty decent meat (may even be good in enchiladas...odd, considering italian spices were used...)...but the recipe probably would not have knocked my socks off without the additions I made to the sandwich.  The horseradish sauce absolutely MADE the meal, as I probably would have been ho-hum about it all, without it!  I will make this again...with the sauce, too - of course!!

text:
First, this was my first use of either a roast or a crockpot - but everything turned out excellent!  I didn't have bay leaves and exchanged the onion salt for onion flakes - Also used 3 cups Swanson's Low Sodium Beef Broth instead of water & 2 italian dressing packets as suggested.  Cooked on high and after a few hours it was still tough so I got worried.  However, after hour 4 it was already very tender.  Shredded and cooked for another hour - Came out fantastic.  Boyfriend and son loved it and I'm making it again today!

THANK YOU for this recipe!  I'm from  Chicago but relocated to California 6 years ago and I miss the food back home DESPERATELY!  This fit the bill!  I followed the recipe as it was stated but I agree with a previous reviewer that it would be better to let the roast cook through and slice thin to be just like the consistency of true Italian beef sandwiches.  I also agree that it's best to use 2 packets of Italian seasoning because while this was very tasty, it could have used a bit more punch.  GREAT recipe!  Thank you Maureen!

text:
I did make a few changes; first, I used sirloin tip roast and I also added 1 can of beef broth.  I cooked it in a Nesco cooker @250-275 degrees for 8 hours.  I refrigerator the roast overnight.  The next morning I sliced the roast thin.  Set it in the crocker pot along with it's own juices (after removing the grease off the top which had solidified) and reheated it for 6-8 hours on LOW.   EXCELLENT - Loved by everyone!

text:
Definitely five stars... after a couple of small changes.  I used Zesty salad dressing mix, and I subbed half the water for beef broth.  I tasted the au jus/broth when I removed the roast to shred, and I thought it needed a little extra ooomph, so I added a second packet of the salad dressing mix.  Delicious.  I melted some mozarella on sub buns, then spooned on the meat and yummy au jus, finally topping the sandwiches with pepperoncini rings.  We dipped them in more au jus, letting the sandwich get reallllly wet before each bite.

I let my roast marinate overnight in the fridge. Also when the roast was done cooking, I sliced it and made a gravy with the 
juices by adding flour and water.. poured that over the meat and served with mashed potatoes and butter carrots. It was 
wonderful.. the gravy was very strong and tasty.. we put that only on the meat.. I felt it was too strong for the potatoes. All in 
all this recipe is now a permanent fixture in my recipe box! Plus when is cooks all day your house smells wonderful!!!

text:
This was absolutely delicious Italian Beef and I live near Chicago and know my Italian Beef!
I used a Chuck roast instead of a rump roast and beef broth instead of water, but all the seasonings in the recipe were used and I used two packets of salad dressing instead of one.
I have a 6 quart Nesco that has a low 225Â° for slow cooking and I cooked it for 9 hours. It was scrumptious! I used French rolls buttered with garlic butter and broiled. Then added mozzarella and melted that under the broiler. I served it with peperoncini  peppers and marinara sauce....yuuuuuuuum! It doesn't get any better than that.
My roast was 4 lbs. and there was a perfect amount of seasoned broth for dipping.
If you love Italian Beef, this is the recipe you want to use. 
Just for reference, this served 3 people 2 meals...plenty of leftovers for us.

text:
Amazing. I followed all the suggested changes from the top comment which included using beef broth instead of water, double the salad seasoning, Chuck roast instead of rump, and shred then put back in crock pot for an hour. My alterations included thinly slicing 1 vidalia onion which was used as a bed for the meat, 1 tsp of Italian seasoning, and 3 bay leaves. I used a hoagie bun that I cut open like a hot dog bun, placed 2 slices of thin provolone inside, and toasted for 2 minutes under the broiler. This created a good base that held all the gravy in without making it overly soggy. Topped it off with Marconi's Hot Giardiniera. Will definitely be making this one again!

I marinated the roast for 2 days then I seared the roast at 400Â° in a electric skillet with diced onion and green pepper. Put roast in pre-heated crock pot. De-glaze skillet with beef stock and pour into crock pot. This is the best Italian beef I have ever had.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
When I visit my mom in Chicago, I find the sandwiches different from what I got sixty years ago.  Now they are much pepperier and instead of two pepperoncinis you often get a pile of gardiniere, which is much hotter.  Be sure to use crusty bread.  (A section of french bread is good.  Many breads will fall apart when soaked in juice.)   Then soak plenty of juice into the bread.  I just put the bread open-side-down atop the juice in the slow cooker for a few seconds to soak it.  You can also skip most of the seasonings and just use two envelopes of dressing mix.  My wife likes to use zesty dressing mix but I like to taste the beef and not just hot pepper, so I prefer regular dressing mix.

text:
This is a great recipe. I have made it probably 5 times now. I do add 2 packages of dry italian salad dressing mix, fresh garlic, one sliced onion, 1 jar of sliced banana peppers, a few pickled jalopenos sliced, I use one can of beef broth and one cup of h20. I used a chuck roast this last time and it was great. I will have to try w/other cuts of beef but that is what the butcher recommended. I cooked it 7-8 hrs on low. This is a family favorite and I will continue to make it over and over and over forever. Serve on crusty rolls w/ provolone cheese and a horseradish mayo and hot peppers.

text:
Such an AMAZING sandwich! I made it with a 3 pound chuck roast instead because I feel it has more flavor meat wise. I used a crusty French bread, after the meat was out of the crock pot I dipped the bread into the leftover juices topped the meat in then added some sauteed red bell pepper and onions. I then used provolone cheese, put the sandwiches in a cast iron skillet in the oven at 425 for about 10 minutes, just until the bread became golden and crusty. My husband is still talking about this amazing sandwich! So easy to prepare as well!

text:
Love this recipe, and I make it often!  I followed previous suggestions to double the seasonings (except the salt), using beef broth instead of water, and used either onion powder or dried onions instead of onion salt.

For those with IC, you might substitute thyme for the black pepper (if you can't tolerate it), leeks for the onion salt, a homemade Italian dressing seasoning (and leave out the onion), and an organic or homemade beef broth/stock.  Seems to work well for me, anyway, though I know everyone's triggers are different.

text:
I have made this recipe on several occasions (with some variations) and it has turned out great each time! The variations was the reason I could not rate this as 5 stars. I think the base recipe is very good and the meat comes out very tender. However I used beef broth instead of just water and a couple tablespoons of Worcestershire sauce. I also like spice, so after I add the salad dressing mixture, I covered the top of the roast with some roasted green chili peppers (with juice) which helps seal the top of the meat and adds to the flavor. Turned out very well and will make again!

text:
I followed the recipe except I cooked a 3 pound bottom round for three hours on high, removed and refrigerated. Once it was cold I sliced it with a meat slicer as thinlly as I could without shredding it.  Before serving I reheated the reserved cooking juices. I then dipped the sliced meat into the hot juice to reheat before placing on buns. I then dunked the whole sandwich bun and all into the juice before topping with giardinera I bought in a jar. Almost as good as Johnnies Italian beef we ate when we visited Chicago.

text:
Ok Im from Chicago and I miss beef sandwiches trust me they are awesome..so I thought lets make it first off the seasoning is way off nothing like a good beef sandwich and chuck?  No you use top round but cooking as long as the recipe states is so wrong and it should NEVER be shredded.  The proper way is onion&garlic powder,Italian seasoning, salt & Pepper.  Coat the meat in a 13x9 pan pour in 2 cups of water and 4 beef boullion cubes/or beef base roast it in a 400 oven 30 min per pound, take out chill the meat overnight or at least 4 hours.  Save the "gravy" Slice meat paper thin then reheat in the juice do NOT leave it in there more then 10 min or it will become like leather.  Thats Italian Beef I really wanted this recipe to be good that I tried but it failed :(

I love a good meal from a crock-pot!

LOVED this - with a few tweaks.  I used chicken broth instead of water, and used a little over half of the meat that the recipe calls for.  I think if I had used a whole 5 pound roast, it would not have been enough liquid.  I also added some dehydrated bell peppers about halfway through (I didn't have any fresh on hand), and added some Italian seasoning.  I did cut out the salt, since the broth had some salt, too.  It turned out really well, and I would definitely make it again, with these changes :D

country:
None
text:
Tasty, but honestly, nothing to write home about.  We absolutely LOVE the Pepperoncini Beef recipe (from this site) and this didn't hold a candle.  Don't get me wrong, everyone liked it ok, but I probably won't make it again.  Used homemade Italian Dressing Mix (also from the site), and used a chuck roast, but kept everything else the same.  Update: second day added a generous sprinkling of more Italian dressing mix and a splash of vinegar.  Ate over rice with some steamed broccoli and it was pretty much amazing.  Definitely the trick for me was lots of extra seasoning, then this really hit the spot!

Great Recipe!  Absolutely delicious. I made it for 10 people and it went way over the top.  I made the substitutions that were recommended in the other reviews using 2 cups of beef stock or broth and 1 cup of water instead of using all water.  I used 2 packages of Good Season Italian dressing mix instead of 1.  I used the chuck roast which I will never use again.  To fatty and the meat shrinks a lot.  I would use a rump roast instead.  Thank you for this great recipe!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is EXCELLENT and VERY EASY to make! My co-workers always ask me if I plan to make these sandwiches whenever we hold an office luncheon. Using some suggestions from other reviewers, I use 3 cups of beef broth (instead of 3 cups of water) and 1 5-lb. chuck roast (instead of a rump roast). For the dry Italian-style salad dressing I use the brand by Good Seasons. In order for the meat to be really tender, I've found that it needs to be cooked on Low for 10 hours, then the meat shredded/pulled apart with a fork, then cooked on Low another 2 hours. Since the meat is juicy, I serve it on nice chewy rolls (I purchase French Hamburger rolls from Publix). This dish produces a lot of au jus so there's plenty for dipping. ENJOY!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This made for a fantastic sandwich!!  I followed the recipe except for replacing the water with beef broth and using a 3 lb chuck roast rather than a 5 lb rump.  My only issue was the amount of grease in the liquid.  I should have trimmed my roast more.  I took it out after about 8 hrs, trimmed the fat, shred the meat, and skimmed as much fat off the top of the juices as I could.  I then put the shredded meat back in the juices and let them cook more on low for another couple hours.  Total time in the slow cooker was about 11 hours.  I served it with sauteed mushrooms, onions, and bell peppers on hoagies with melty provolone.  Man!! Absolutely delicious!!!!

Display Name:
wingerone
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It was a pretty decent sandwich, not anything as good as all the reviews.  I had really high hopes for this recipe.  It must be a Chicago thing.   You know, when you grow up with something it has a special place in your heart.  I did as most of the reviews suggested.  It didn't need any salt and used garlic power instead of salt.  Replaced water and bouillon with broth, 2 packs of italian salad dressing.  I did what one suggested and sliced it and returned the meat to the sauce to cook more.  Don't slice.  Shredding is much better for this type of sandwich.  Also, make sure you use a real crusty roll.  As juicy as this meat is a softer roll just falls apart.  This just needed something.  If I make it again I'll try adding a tbs or 2 of tomato paste and see how that works.

text:
This is a great way to cook a roast.  I only had about a 2 pound sirloin tip, so I cut all the spice measurements in half, except I did use the entire package of dressing mix and instead of water I used a whole can of beef broth.  I omitted the bay leaf because I didn't have one.  I cooked it for about 4 hours on high and it turned out wonderful.  Instead of making sandwitchs with it, I served it over rice, awesome, but I cannot wait to make a sandwitch with the leftovers tomorrow.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The only reason for the 4 stars was that the original recipe needed a little bit of an upgrade for my tastes.  I followed the instructions of another reviewer below and used 2.5 lbs of chuck instead of rump roast for better separation on the beef. I also used 2 packs of italian dressing.  

The beef was a little salty with the ingredients listed as well.  I chose to use onion powder instead of salt and omitted the teaspoon of salt since the rest of the ingredients were pretty heavy in sodium anyway.  It also helped to let the beef sit in the pot with the juices after shredding for a couple extra hours to keep the meat juicy and soft.  

Provalone is my cheese of choice if using the meat for sandwiches, and a toasted roll is a must.  Throw on some grilled sweet peppers, onions, and mushrooms, and this recipe is an absolute knockout.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I thought this tasted pretty good. I don't normally care for the broth from the crock pot, but this one had a lot of flavor. I let it cool down, skimmed the oil off the top, and then drizzled the broth on the rolls. I wasn't sure at first if the sandwich would have enough flavor on its own and caramelized onion and pepper rings on the stove on medium to add to the sandwiches. The only downside is it is kind of salty, for my taste, and I wasn't sure of the exact bun best for this. I went for a heartier one and I think a less dense sub roll would have been best. For some reason though I thought it was better the next day and we used the skimmed broth as an au jus type dipping sauce. It was very tasty that way. The bread, meat, and au jus to dip was all it needed.

Display Name:
Prescott Grandma

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Soooo good!  I used 3 C of water with 1 T Better Than Bullion Beef paste.  Next time I will try 2 tsp of the paste.  It was just a bit salty.  I didn't add the salt, used onion powder instead of onion salt, but I did use 2 packages of the dressing mix.  I use a 5 pound chuck roast.  After 8 hours it was falling apart, so I shredded and put it back in the juice for 1 1/2 hours.  I was amazed how the meat soaked up the juice, so be sure to do this.  I had cut most of the fat off the roast, but there was still more than I would like to see on top after cooling.  Next time I will use the suggestion to separate the meat from the juice and let it cool overnight, to skim the fat off, before adding the shredded meat to the juice.  I served it on Hoagie mult-grain rolls (Everyone used 1/2 roll and ate it open faced) with grilled onions and fire roasted red peppers.   Also served cole slaw and a fruit salad.  Everyone really enjoyed it and it couldn't have been easier to prepare for a large group. Thank you so much for the "keeper".

text:
this is AWESOME!! the first time I made this - I followed the directions and it was good - if you are making a full roast - use 2 packets of the italian seasoning and add a tbsp minced garlic to it - also, sear the meat before you put it in the slow cooker - mix some flour and you favorite seasonings (season salt pepper onion powder garlic powder) shred it about and hour or two before it is done - at walmart they have different types of bread - my favorite was the garlic parmesan - i tried the everything bread and it was good too - kinda salty though. I sauteed the onions and bell peppers instead of mixing them in with the meat - serve with provalone cheese - YUMMMMMMMYYYYYYYY

This recipe is soooooo good! I read a couple of other reviews and used 2 packets of italian dressing and 2 cups of beef broth and 1 cup of water.  After shredding the beef, I added sliced green and red peppers to the mix and let it cook for about an hour.  I served it on homemade french rolls with provolone cheese and carmelized sweet onions.  We were in heaven!  Took the left overs today to my mom's house and everyone there loved it too!  I will be making this again and again!!!

text:
Used equivalent to 2 pkg dressing (home-made from recipe from this site)mix, used beef broth in place of water. Use onion powder and omitted salt. Cooked day ahead, shredded and refrigerated, reheated next day. This allowed the flavors to develop. Served on Italian rolls I sliced spread with butter and garlic and broiled til golden brown. Piled on the beef along with roasted red and green sweet peppers and mozzarella & provolone cheeses. Put back under broiler til cheese was melted, Served with juice for dipping. WOW! Fabulous! 4/12/2012 revised: I tried using one pkg Good Seasons dressing mix plus equivalent to 1 pkg homemade mix. I forgot and added salt that the recipe calls for and it made the juice WAY too salty. However, the meat was  not too salty. I used venison roast and this provided a juicy full flavored sandwich. Did not make ahead of time, served right after cooking. SUPERB! Thanks for sharing such a great recipe!

text:
I've used this recipe for both dinner with my husband, as well as for a medium-sized Christmas party (about 30 people-doubled the recipe) and had fantastic results both times!  I used a little less salt and pepper, had to substitute onion powder for the onion salt, and had to substitute garlic salt for the garlic powder.  I followed the suggestion to shred the meat 1-2 hours before it is done...very easy to do.  I have also used chicken breasts instead of beef and was quite pleased with the results!  My husband thought the chicken was a little too "bold" on its own but having it on bread provided the balance it needed.

text:
In fairness, I have never been to Chicago to try the actual sandwich and I am eager and curious to do just that. 
I added beef boullion to the water and used two pkgs of I talian dressing mix (G.S.).
The house DID smell deliciousand I was quite excited! However I cooked it for 8 hours on low,and it was falling apart tender. As much as the smell was wonderful, it tasted like good but bland pot roast. The roasted red peppers and cheese on the sandwich were all that saved it. 
It was an all day not bad sandwich. I am not sure if maybe adding the seasoning later or using more if the delicious smelling flavor would have stayed?
I took half of the leftovers and made Allrecipes beef and cabbage soup, and the other half I turned into a batch of chili.  It could have been delicious I guess if the flavors lasted so less time or more of the ingredients

country:
None
text:
So easy and tasty too! I have made this recipe for SuperBowl Sunday the last 4 years. Absolutely wonderful. 
I have followed others suggestions to use beef broth instead of water. I omit the salt all together and use onion powder. Definately double the italian dressing mix and I have never used a bay leaf. Some complain about it being to peppery but I have found that while the broth mixture is quite strong the meat is not. Due the the amount that I make, sometimes double, I have started cooking it a day in advance. Let it cool, shred it, then refrigerate overnight. Set on low about 4-5 hours before serving.

I usually don't like this kind of sandwich, but my husband does & it got rave reviews, so thought I'd give it a whirl.  He gave it 4 stars, my 10 year old son gave it 4 1/2 out of 5.  It was a hit.  I followed the suggestions of using beef broth instead of water, using a chuck roast instead of a rump roast, used 2 packets of salad dressing mix, & shredded the meat after 8 hours & cooked it the remaining time after shredding.

This was great.  I used beef brisket b/c it was really cheap and it was excellent. I just left in in the slow cooker on low before I left the house in the morning and 10 hours later, voila!  I sauteed some onions and peppers and broiled butttered buns.  Then I put the meat and veggies on and melted mozarella on the top and bottoms. Excellent! And the recipe doesn't call for broth so since there were reviews that said it was too salty I justed used water as instructed and there was no issue with the salt level. Maybe you should try following the recipe and not give the recipe a bad review when you modified it.

text:
Ok, let me preface this by saying that I have never had Italian Beef sandwiches so I have nothing to compare this taste to. After reading many of the reviews, I was hesitant to make the recipe as given, but I didn't have any beef broth to add, plus I thought that made it sound more French Dip-ish, so decided to give it a shot as written. My roast was only 2.5 pounds, but I made with the ingredients directed for a 5 lb roast, shredded the beef about an hour before I planned to serve the sandwiches, waited an hour and then tasted.  I was not impressed, very bland and pot roast tasting....so I added half an onion, half a jar of peppercini juice and about a quarter a jar of peppercini's, and another salad dressing packet...waited another hour (smelled awesome- we were starving!) and it was AMAZING. Hubby moaned when he dipped in the juice and took a bite. Everyone agreed this was a keeper, and if I had not had to modify so much, I would give it a 5...made as directed its a 2.

text:
I'm giving this 5 stars b/c it was easy; however, I've never cooked the spices and mix - simply add to the crockpot.  I used beef broth in place of the water and used 3 packets of the Italian seasoning mix. I put two packets in with the roast (used 6 lbs as this was for a tailgate) when I first put it on and cooked it on low for 8 hours. I then shredded, removed the access fat, and put back in the crock pot and added an onion and another packet of the dry Italian seasoning mix and cooked another hour. I served on french bread and had provolone cheese available. This was a huge hit at the game!

I did not have all the ingredients, I was missing basil, onion salt, parsley, and garlic powder.  I used Onion and Roasted Garlic soup mix instead, I used the dry Italain salad dressing, and teaspoon each of, garlic plus, Italiano seasoning, fresh ground pepper, 3 bay leaves, (mine were small), 5 pound rump roast, 1 can of beef broth and water to equal 3 cups, did not add salt because of the soup mix.  I trimmed all the llittle bits of fat off the roast, took the strings off. and followed the recipe directions.  The meat fell apart with a fork, I added the meat back to the yummy juice. I melted cheddar cheese on warm NAAN  bread  piled on the beef.  My husband LOVED it.  I will make this again and will have the missing ingredients.  But this version was wonderful!

country:
None
text:
This is my 11 yo sonâs favorite meal. I have made it many times over the years. Today I am tweaking and using a 32 oz box of beef stock in place of the water, omitted the salt, but used the 1/2 tsp onion salt and only used 1/4 tsp of pepper. I added fresh garlic and 1/2 cup of sherry.  Otherwise made it as is. I used a 3lb chuck roast and cooked it on low for 9 hours. During the last hour, I threw in fresh sliced mushrooms and sliced onions. I put the meat, mushrooms, onions and provolone cheese on hoagie rolls and placed under the broiler. We then use the au jus for French dip sandwiches and serve with hot mashed potatoes. Yummy!

My hubbby loved this!  I split and toast some Cotton's French twin loaf bread with a little mayo & the au jus on the side for dipping.  Creates a po boy that is embarassingly easy.  I was a little concerned about the veggies in the jars, but they cooked down to almost nothing.  Snuck those veggies in on my carnivore husband by mashing the remaining whole ones and he never knew it.  It is more flavorful when I season the meat the day before cooking.  4 stars for flavor (something is still missing, but I'm not sure what) and 5 stars for how easy it is to cook.

This is positively outstanding! My family was blown away by how good this was. As other reviewers noted, I used 3 cups of beef stock instead of water, no salt, 2 (.7 ounce) packages of dry Italian salad dressing mix, and a chuck roast. I used the seasonings as noted in the recipe. The au jus is to die for! For my sandwiches, I topped them with sauteed onions, peppers and mushrooms, added a slice of provolone cheese. Popped it under the broiler to melt the cheese. Dinner was fantastic!! Serve this to your family and you'll be a rock star ... guaranteed.

text:
My family enjoyed the sandwiches. It's not exactly like a Chicago-style Italian beef, but it's still delicious. I used 3 cups of beef stock (no salt added) and about 1/2 a cup of zinfandel for the liquid instead of water. I also used 2 packages of italian dressing, as others suggested. I used a chuck roast and it turned out great. My roast was just over 4 pounds and it cooked fairly quickly. It was done within 7 hours. I shredded it at 7 hours and turned the crockpot down to low/warm for another hour and a half or so. I'll make this again.

I also used mostly beef broth and two salad dressing packets.  I also added some crushed red pepper. I had to freeze two more meals of this stuff because it makes so much.  It freezes great!  I just warm it up again and add a little more beef broth to the meat.

Like others have suggested, I used 3 cans low-sodium beef broth in place of water, omitted the salt, used garlic powder instead of garlic salt, and used two packets of Italian seasoning. I also used chuck roast instead of rump roast. I shredded the meat an hour before it was time to eat and let it simmer in the broth. We served the beef on toasted kaiser and hoagie rolls, topped with provolone cheese.

The final product was delicious.  This recipe was used as a guideline with the following changes:    1.  Water was substituted with beef broth. 2.  I used 1/2 bottle Italian dressing. 3.  All of the other seasonings and spices were substituted with about 2 tbsps of grilling salt combo. Everyone in my family was impressed with this and would like for me to prepare it again.

Display Name:
prgr2007

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7059540.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have to give this 4 stars because I deviated a bit from the original recipe. I used beef broth instead of water. I also used a 2.5 lb roast but kept the originally called for amounts of seasoning and water/broth. I put it in the crock pot for 3 hours on high and about 6 more hours on low. About an hour before I took it off I shredded the meat so it could soak up the flavor - this is a pretty essential step. The result was excellent. I don't know if I'd love it so much with water, but the broth was nice. Definitely use low sodium broth! I skipped the salt entirely the second time I made it, and that was a good decision. It's just too salty otherwise. Served on toasted hoagie bread with red and green peppers, sweet red onions, and provolone cheese. This is definitely a recipe we will make again. Thanks.

text:
This was excellent and very easy to put together in the morning before leaving for work.  I didn't have any onion salt so I used some onion powder instead.  I put some baby carrots in the bottom of my crockpot and let them cook in the juices all day long.  I pulled them out when I pulled the roast out to shred.  I added a little bit of cornstarch to the juices to thicken it up a bit before adding the shredded meat back in.  I let the meat soak up in the liquid for about another half hour before serving.  So tender and full of flavor!

This was SO good. Perfectly seasoned and delicious! I used beef broth instead of water, and didn't have any onion salt, so I left that out. I cooked on high for 2 hours, then on low for about 7...I shredded the meat and let it soak in the juices for about 3 hours before serving. Even though I only had a 2.5 lb roast, I kept the seasonings the same. This was awesome served on homemade French Rolls. Next time I'll serve with peppers and melted cheese. Thank you!

city:

country:
None
text:
I followed this recipe exactly as listed and it turned out great. I used a 5 1/2 lb roast. It turned out very tender. One thing to remember with these Italian Beefs - the meat will be shredded not sliced. I believe sliced is the traditional way beef sandwiches are done. After the meat was done I shredded it right in the crock pot. Keep all the juices. This is where the flavor is! We ate our beef on french rolls that were buttered with butter and garlic. After the meat is on the roll we top with moz. cheese or prov. cheese and put under the broiler for the cheese to melt and toast. Add some giardinera for an extra kick.

text:
This turned out great!! Tastes just like the Italian Beef I had in Chicago. I used a 3 pound roast, but left all of the spice amounts the same. I didn't have onion salt, so subbed it with 3/4 tsp. onion powder and 1.5 tbsp. dried minced onion. Also added three beef bouillon cubes, 2 tbsp. jarred minced garlic and doubled the italian dressing mix. Nothing ever tastes quite right in my slow cooker, so I cooked this in my cast iron dutch oven at 350 for 90 minutes. Pretty easy, even for a weeknight meal!

Wonderful, Wonderful, Wonderful!! I made this for family visiting out of state and everyone raved. I used 2 Italian seasoning packets but will use 3 next time. I also added the juice from the jar of pepperoncini jar. I added about 1/2 a jar of the pepperoncini's and then kept the jar available for those who wanted to add more to their sandwich. My mother doesn't like spicy food but she loved this. All the rest of us added more pepperoncini's and the beef was gone in one sitting for 4 people. I made homemade rolls and they complemented this meal wonderfully!

text:
Be sure to read the reviews on this one before you make it.  As suggested in many reviews, I used a chuck roast, beef broth instead of water and I doubled the amount of salad dressing.  I shredded it in the crock pot and left it on an additional 1/2 hour to soak in the juices.  I assembled the meat and cheese on sub rolls and put them in the oven for about 10 minutes to crisp the bread and melt the cheese.  My son and his friends loved them!  Next time I will be sure to have mushrooms and onions to add on top!

text:
I read many of the reviews and made some modifications, like double the Italian seasoning, and using beef broth instead of water. I also used a bottom round roast because it was on sale at the grocery store and it's lower in fat. I was afraid this cut of meat would turn out dry and leathery because it has relatively less fat than other cuts, but it was just the opposite. It was juicy and moist, and it shredded beautifully. Don't forget to put the juice on your roll--it's well worth it! The flavor was great, and very authentic! My husband, who's a pretty picky eater, told me this needed a place in the "rotation" of recipes! Success!

text:
Amazing! Used a 2.5 pound chuck roast with all the spices & seasonings suggested for a 5 pound roast, along with 2 cans of beef broth in place of the water. Cooked it on low for 10 hours, shredded the beef & returned it to the crock pot with some sliced red onion and bell pepper for an additional 2 hours. Piled the meat (and veggies) into a split hoagie roll, topped it with provolone and stuck it under the broiler for a minute to melt the cheese. As I said, amazing!

text:
This recipe was delicious. I took the advice of the poster on top. (Thank you so much for compiling all of the best advice into your review!) I used a 2.5 lb chuck roast and cooked it with all of the seasonings for a 5 lb roast + I added an extra italian dressing packet. My family is big on flavor! I cooked for 7 hrs and then removed the meat to "shred". It practically fell into shreds. There was minor work involved in picking out the fat. I too returned the meat to the juice and then served on crusty rolls with a side of potato salad. The next day I reheated the left overs and they were even BETTER stuffed into flour tortillas with cheddar cheese. The flavor lends itself well to mexican dishes also! Thanks for the recipe. Will definitely make it again!

country:

text:
Oh wow! This has got to be one of the best crockpot recipes I have ever made! And I have made a lot! If you are considering making this, you really should. It was fantastic! My changes: Used about 10 oz of dry Italian mix, used 3 cups of beef broth, used a 3 pound chuck roast, after about 8 hours of cooking on low, I shredded the meat then let it simmer on warm for another hour. Put on toasted rolls with provolone cheese. It was phenomenal! My meat was pretty fatty, so while i shredded it, I pulled off the fat. Next time I'll try and separate the fat from the broth once I get the meat out of the pot (before shredding). It's so good, you don't even need the bread! You've got to try it!!

As is, I give this recipe 4 stars.  I made this with some slight changes and with them, can rate it a 5!  I used a 3 lb roast and used 2 cups of beef broth instead of water.  I also added some chopped onion for flavor.  I doubled up on the basil and oregano and added a dash of red pepper flake.  After shredding the beef, I added a tad bit more garlic and salt & pepper.  I did not use a bay leaf at all.  I served the beef on toasted hoagie buns with monterey jack cheese.  Delicious!

text:
I made this because the reviews made it sound scrumptious.  I pretty much followed the recipe to the letter and was completely unimpressed when I served it that night.  My husband too, thought it pretty ho-hum.
The next night, HOWEVER, after 24 hours of refrigerator ripening...my whole family was (almost) fighting over it.  We couldn't get enough. The meat is flavorful and very tender.  You could do almost nothing to it...plain meat on bread, and it would still be very tasty.
Keeping this recipe.  Makes a lot so it'd be perfect to make one day and serve to a crowd the next, just by reheating.

text:
Delicious and so easy! I took the advice of some other reviewers and made the following substitutions:

used beef broth instead of water; 
used onion powder instead of onion salt; used fresh garlic instead of garlic powder.

Used a 2.5 lb roast and a full packet of Italian dressing mix.

Leftovers made a hearty soup - added vegetable broth, Italian-style stewed tomatoes, fresh vegetables and barley. Family loved it.

This was pretty good, though I did change some of the ingredients a bit.  I took another reviewer's advice and used beef broth instead of water and added green peppers during the last hour.  I also used fresh garlic and onion in place of powder.  There seemed to be a little too much black pepper for my taste.  I grew up in Chicago and love Italian beef, and this is nothing like what I am used to.  That being said, this was still a good sandwich and easy to make, though I think I'll cut down on the pepper a little next time.

text:
I originally made this for my son because I'm not a big fan of italian beef, but I ended up loving it.  I followed some of the suggestions such as doubling the italian dressing mix, using beef broth instead of water, omitting the salt, and using onion powder instead of onion salt.  Also, I used 3lbs of chuck roast.  I didn't change anything else.  It was slightly on the salty side so I made it again using only one package of italian mix but then it wasn't flavorful enough.  I'll have to make some tweaks to get it just right, but, overall, this is a great italian beef recipe.

text:
A really great beef recipe. I did substitute beef broth for the water, and then omitted all of the salts (subbing with garlic and onion powder) - using salts in addition to the salty broth substitute probably does make it quite salty, but without I had no problems. I also used the rump roast as specified, cooked for 12+ hours on low, and while it was about as tender as this cut gets chuck would yield a more tender dinner. I like how lean trimmed rump roasts are, so personally I will make it with rump anyways. Thanks very much for sharing :)

text:
SALTY! SALTY! SALTY! I followed the advice of momsavedbygrace, who usually has great tips (thanks) but this time, for me it turned out so salty that my husband and I tossed out the leftovers. I   followed the recipe exactly, per the changes in the above-mentioned review; even used a bigger roast -- about 2.88 pounds. I added the two dressing packages as she suggested. I don't even think omitting the extra salt the recipe calls for would have made the difference here. I may try this again, but with 1 and a half packets of the dressing, increase other spices individually, omit the salt altogether and use a 5lb roast as the recipe suggests. I recommend adding peppers and mushrooms too; this just lacked something -- not salt though!

text:
I don't know what I did wrong with this one. I got a chuck roast which everyone suggested & I cooked it on high for 4 hours. I guess I should have woken up really early & cooked it on low for 10 hours. I used broth instead of water & 2 pkgs of dressing mix per reviews, & no onion salt. My husband had a fit when he tried to shred it, it was tough so it took a long time. After it was shredded we put it back in the crockpot for half an hour to soak in the broth. It was good on rolls with mozzarella & roasted red peppers, I put it under the broiler  to melt the cheese. One thing that grossed me out, was that I trimmed the fat off the meat very well before making it. After being in the fridge the next day there were little hard pieces of fat all over the meat. I guess you have to buy a roast with no fat at all. I might try this again but cook it on low for 10-12 hours, I wouldn't recommend doing it on high. Thanks.

text:
Very good!! I needed something to help with a busy week, and this seemed like the ticket...the beef flavor (and smell!) is outstanding, and my husband and kids all are really appreciating it. I made a few changes - used 2 cans of beef broth (low sodium) and 2 pkgs of Zesty Italian as others recommended. Left out the salt and used onion powder instead of onion salt. Left out the parsley and bay leaf. It was still a little salty and the liquid had cooked down a lot (I cooked it 5 hrs on high, 5 hrs on low, shredded the beef, then 45 min on warm), so I will add a cup of water next time. Served on Portuguese rolls - will probably do a heartier roll next time. A keeper - it's gone into "Mom's Cookbook" where only the great ones go.

text:
Absolutely the BEST Italian Beef EVER!!  I used 5 lb top round, 1 can beef broth, 2 cups water, 2 pkgs dry italian dressing mix and all the other seasonings as listed.  After 5 hours on high, I shred the roast, added one 16 oz jar of mild gardienera and turned down to low for one additional hour -- To Die For!!  Also served on baked garlic bread rolls with melted mozzarella cheese. No more restaurant Italian Beefs for us -- these are better.

text:
This is the BEST italian beef recipe I have found. I have great success using a bottom round roast. The only things I do differently are very basic. I use "zesty" italian dressing mix and, since they cook all day anyway, I don't see the need to preboil the water, herbs & spices. I just mix all of them together in a bowl, pour it over the beef in the slow cooker and turn it on.  Tastes great!

text:
I made this early in the summer for a change (I usually do the BBQ sauce thing for beef/pork sandwiches), and I'm glad I tried it! An excellent way to prepare meat for a simple and yummy (and maybe not-so-elegant) dinner. Add some salad and/or fries, you're set! My husband loved the change, too. I used a 2Â½ pound roast (I don't remember what cut, but it was the cheapest cut I could find) and cut the seasonings back to half (except the dressing mix, I put the entire package in). I also cut back a little more on the pepper and salt as I don't like too much pepper and there's so much salt in the dressing plus onion salt... Excellent! Thanks for the recipe!

text:
My family really enjoyed this recipe. I also used 2 packages of dressing mix and low sodium beef broth. I used 2 boneless chuck roasts (they were all very small at the store) and a whole onion chopped and also fresh garlic. We made sandwiches that I melted under the broiler with provolone. Served with green peppers and onions. I used the leftovers in burritos. They could also be used for taquitos as well. The chuck roast shreds better than a rump roast and is also much cheaper. The meat does smell terrific and the taste is even better. Thanks for such a great recipe.

OK, I have to say this recipe was defienetly 5 star.  Just the smell alone- while it was cooking in the crock pot brout back so many memories for me.  I used to live in Chicago and I ate italian beefs all the time.  Now I live in FLorida and haven't found a good place where they serve this dish.  The only thing I didn't like was I sliced mine, but it wasn't as thin as it should be.  You also must serve with sweet peppers, as in green peppers and onions, would be also good with mottzarella cheese.  I like mine with gardinare- HOT and SPICY please!  OH Yeah one more thing.  Dip your bread in the juice- serve bread almost soggy, if you must use a knife and fork.  Now if someone can post a recipe for a tamale, I'll be in heaven.  Thanks Maureen

text:
This made very good sandwiches.  I used 2 packages of salad dressing. I tasted a piece of the meat before shredding, though, and realized that the outside was flavorful, but the inside meat lacked flavor.  So I shredded away, and took another reviewer's advice to cook the shredded meat for an additional hour.  This made all the difference.  Provolone or Swiss cheese melted on top of the sandwiches is a definite must.  By the way, it tasted even better the next day--my son loved it.

country:

text:
Very good as written, but the salt and pepper were over overpowering to the other "italian" spices, for me. Due to reviews, 2nd time, I reduced pepper to 1/2 tsp, used onion POWDER (instead of onion salt),added 2 cups broth (I had on hand beef AND chicken) and 1 cup water to cover. Slow cooked a 3# (not 5#) sirloin flat roast for 12 hours then shredded right in the roaster)and added MORE dried spice (about 2 tsp. Italian) and let it set, on low, in juices for about 15 mnutes more. I liked the italian spice added near the end for a fresher flavor. With the smaller roast, I had about 2 cups of yummy broth left over for dipping. Thank you Maureen, for a great recipe that we just changed a little for our tastes.

I have never bothered to write a review but I have to say this one is good...really GOOD!! I did a couple of things different.  I used one can of condensed beef broth and two cans of water..instead of the 3 cups of water suggested. I used one packet of Italian dressing Plus one packet of zesty Italian dressing mix.  I also added about 3 tablespoons of the dried onions from a package of Lipton onion soup mix(just the onions not the powder).I used a not so good roast and was concerned because after 5 hours of cooking it was very tough...but went back to work and came home and it was Fabulous...yum yum...its a must try!!!

text:
I too used to live in Chicago and would get Italian beef sandwiches constantly.  I had no clue that other areas of the country didn't have these things!  Seeing as so many others from the area rated this highly, I thought I'd give it a chance.  The first time I made it, it was okay, but not quite what I expected.  The juices were exactly what I remembered, which gave me hope.  My husband and children loved it though.  So the next time I made it, when the roast was tender enough, I shredded it, then let it simmer some more.  This time, it was just right!  I sliced up a green pepper and cooked it in a pan with the juices to put on the sandwiches.  This is now a staple recipe in our house.  Now if I can only figure out how to make it with sliced beef...

text:
Absolutely delicious!! I followed the changes suggested & had to give it 5 stars. The suggested changes: add beef broth to water,  doubled the Italian dressing package, chuck roast instead of rump roast, doubled seasonings, & added Italian peppers at the end. One reviewer said, the wetter the better & I found that to be true!! That was my first time intentionally making a wet sandwich & I loved it- the juice was everything! Make sure to use thick hoagie bread!

userID:
26260170
Display Name:
lil qwerty
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
29
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7135701.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So over the weekend, I decided to buy a London Broil, only because it was buy one get one at the store. I never cooked w/this cut of meat, before, & didn't know that it's a pretty dry, tough meat when prepared. Tried making a pot roast the other day w/one & it was just very underwhelming, to say the least. Swore I would never buy this cut of meat, again. Still, I had this leftover one that I had to figure out a solution for, really didn't want to freeze it but didn't want to chuck it out, either. 

Stumbled on this recipe during my search, decided I'd experiment w/it & have another meal ready to make as a backup, in the event that it turned out like my sad dry pot roast.

The London Broil was ~2.5lbs but I still used the same ingredients & amounts, which I'm happy I did as I don't feel like there would've been enough juice if I halved it all. Only other difference was that I used Beef Stock in place of water & used 2 packets of Italian Seasoning, as suggested by others. 

The house smelled absolutely divine while it was cooking. At the 10 hour mark I checked on it & it was falling apart. I shred the meat up, sauteed 2 green peppers on the stovetop, then returned it all back into the liquid to cook for an add'l 2 hours. Served on hard rolls w/melted Provolone & I made sure to wet each roll. 

Chicago born & raised, so I've had my fair share of Italian Beef & have to say this was absolutely delicious & deserves more than 5 stars!! Will be making again, for sure! Tysm!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2019-11-06T04:21:16.437
helpfulCount:
0
userID:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was raised in Chicago and know a good Italian beef "sangwich" when I taste one! I used 2 (14.5 ounce) cans of beef broth in place of water. Also drained the juice from a 12 ounce jar of pepper rings and added the juice to the saucepan, along with a packet of Au Jus mix. I din't need to add salt. Those were the only changes I made, other than using an 5 pound Eye of the Round roast trimmed of fat. Cooked on low 9 hours, and while the meat shredded easily and flavor was excellent, it was still a bit tough.  Next time I think I'll cut the roast into large chunks  instead of cooking it in 1 piece, to see if it cooks better. Thanks for the recipe!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2019-10-31T14:51:47.98

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a hit at a recent party but I did make some changes that just made sense to me.  I used a Chuck Roast instead of the Butt roast which just fell apart nicely after cooking. I used beef broth instead of water and will only use 2 cups next time as there was a lot of unnecessary juice. I diced a large onion instead of the onion powder which just made sense and for people who say they don't like onion they will not see them at all in the finished product. I also used minced garlic instead of the garlic powder. Lastly is used two packets of the Italian Seasoning mix to give it extra flavor. The meat was nice and moist after letting it cook the last two hours after shredding and putting it back in. Very flavorful by itself but people loved topping it off with a pepper and onion mixture I fried up in a skillet with some of the broth from the crock pot.
Review:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was VERY GOOD.  I made the following changes based on others reviews. I used three cups of beef broth and doubled the spices. I did use a rump roast (Aldi was out of chuck) and after 5 hours on high it fell apart. I shredded the meat and then let it sit in the juice for 1/2 hour. I sauteed red onion, red pepper and mushrooms. Piled the meat and veggie mix on a bun and covered it with a slice of provolone. Put it under the broiler for a couple of minutes to let the cheese melt. The only thing I am going to do differently is get a better bun. I just had hamburger rolls available and they weren't strong enough to hold everything. I am going to use the left overs in a stir fry later on this week.

My parents made Italian Beef that was similar.  If you want thinly sliced beef refrigerate the roast after cooking and take to a butcher shop.  Sometimes they will put the beef on a slicer and slice the roast for a nominal charge.

text:
I have made this a number of times for many years.  My picky family loves this recipe.  I do, however, cut the water back by at least 1/2 of what it calls for.   I use either 1 & 1/2 cups or 1 cup of water instead of adding extra  Italian seasoning packet.  I also use a 1/2 tsp of oregano instead of a full tsp.  As a role, you should use half the amount of oregano to basil for recipes.  This recipe is very easy to make.  It is very good on a crusty roll/bun!  I use a chuck roast also.  You can top it with roasted green pepper or relish and of course some provolone or mozzarella. Yum

country:

text:
A friend turned me on to this recipe pretty much as-is.  Seems to be a standard as far as I can tell, and oh man, there's a reason!  MOUTH WATERING!!!   I put mine on an open-faced hoagie roll (Martins Hoagie Rolls, my favs) .   I open it up all the way, spread mayo on it, put the shredded beef on it (making sure to cover all the bread so it won't get burnt) and then slapped a couple of slices of provolone on top.  Stuck it under the broiler for about 3 minutes or so and boom bap, baboom bap, THUNDERSTUCK!!!!

It couldn't be easier to make.  Plop it in the slow cooker, put the water and seasonings in, put the lid on, push the button,  find a way to kill a few hours, and then dig in!

As far as something to side it with, don't worry about it, you probably won't have room left for anything else.

That is not a French Dip. That is Italian beef.  A French Dip is thinly sliced roast beef, piled on a grilled, buttered torpedo roll with NOTHING else. No cheese, no onions, no mushrooms. 
Served with a side of super beefy au jus and super crispy French fries. Thatâs what a French Dip is.

text:
I've only had the real thing once in Chicago, but I thought it sounded perfect for guys poker night - and I was right!  Followed recipe, except I cut my roast into 5 pieces and browned them each a bit in olive oil, before adding to the crock pot.  I always prefer beef that has been browned before the crock pot, and I was in a big hurry - only had 4 hours, so I figured this would speed up the cooking.  Just delicious - be sure to save the juice, bcs my Chicago friend told me they are best served "wet" with a pepperocini on top.  All of the guys raved about them.  A new favorite for our parties.

text:
Great recipe! Used beef broth instead of water, used 2 packages of Italian dressing, and used 6 lb chuck roast from Costco. After slow cooking on low for about 8 hours I shredded meat. Right before serving I drained the meat and saved the broth. Cooled the broth enough to pour fat off. Then put meat back in slow cooker to serve with about  1 cup of broth and served the rest of broth as au jus on the side. Served on crusty mini French rolls toasted with Provolone cheese. Fantastic!

None
text:
This recipe is absolutely delicious. I substituted beef stock instead of water, used 2 packages of Zesty Italian Salad Dressing mix instead of 1, got some beef fat (free) from the butcher and used about 1/4 pound. I put the beef fat in the pot first and cooked it until there was some liquid beef fat in the bottom of the pot. I used bottom round instead of a rump roast because there is more flavor with this type of cut. I added the beef after the fat cooked a little bit and then added all other ingredients. Slow cooked it, shredded the meat and put it back into the broth. Cooked until tender. A family favorite.

text:
I used chuck roast as suggested and found that though it was very tasty it was extremely fatty. I had to pull chunks of fat and connective tissue off the roast while shredding. I think this should be made ahead of time and all juices drained and cooled in the fridge long enough so the fat can be skimmed off before adding the juices back to the shredded beef. That being said it was delicious served with peppers and onions and cheese melted over French rolls!

Fabulous - like being back home on Chicago South Side! Substitutions, beef stock instead of water. 2t onion flakes instead of 1t onion salt. 2t dried minced garlic instead of 1t garlic powder.  Then, double all the spices (makes it 4 each of onion/garlic). Shred meat and return to juice at least an hour before serving. My picky eater friend had 4 helpings!

text:
Highly recommend! To give it 5 stars, double all the seasonings except the salt (I do not add any salt). I cooked it in the oven at 275 degrees in a covered dutch oven for 10 hours. I served it with a choice of hamburger buns or whole wheat tortillas. Both were delicious! If you like extra spicy sandwiches, top your sandwich with Tuscan Garden's brand of "Giardiniera Hot" (a blend of hot peppers, celery, cauliflower and carrots in soybean oil). Enjoy!!

text:
Living outside of Chicago the flavors of this Italian beef are pretty spot on, problem is my wife has never had an Italian beef, she doesn't eat red meat. Not a problem. I use FROZEN CHICKEN(3lb bag) most of the time for this recipe. It is just as delicious as it would be with beef. I add 2/1-2 cups beef broth and 1 cup of water, in case u want it wet, and also the 2 packets of Italian seasoning. I always seem to add some more basil and oregano to taste. Follow the directions like you would and enjoy. I prefer chuck roast for this, but for all you people who do not eat red meat enjoy the flavors of an Italian beef, but call it Italian chicken.

userID:
7752818
Display Name:
Cab
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5976785.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First time making this recipe and let me say that the beef and gravy (ok.. au jus, for many of you) was spectacularly good! Meat so tender... gravy so flavorful! 
This is going on the Turkey Day menu!!

As far as using it for Italian Beef Sandwiches... eh.. well... the problem I had was more about texture than flavor. Being a Chicagoan... having eaten innumerable Italian Beefs in my long life... this "pulled beef" texture just doesn't work well. The beef is more a mash once you put it on the sandwich instead of the almost paper thin strips that it should be. 

I didn't think that would matter, but it does.. quite a bit.

But since I don't have a meat slicer and will certainly NOT be buying one.. this was a good effort but ultimately, disappointing as far as using it for IB sandwiches.

BUT I will certainly be using this recipe for cooking beef in the future!

I made two changes to the recipe.. I doubled the Italian dressing mixture (instead of buying it in packets, I used a recipe on this site to create it). And I added the equivalent of two bullion cubes using "Better than bullion-- Beef" (my fave beef and chicken bullion solution).

Doubling the Italian mix worked really well... but using that much bullion was frankly unnecessary. Next time I will use none or just one bullion.

text:
This turned out great!  I followed the advice of others and used a chuck roast.  I bought a 2.5lb roast.  I doubled the Italian seasoning and left out the bay leaf because I didn't have it.  I also used fried minced onions instead of onion salt.  Those were the only changes.  I cooked mine on low for 5 hours.  It was tender enough to cut, so I did and then put the cut meat back in the crockpot for an hour.  I also added sliced  peppercini's, sliced mild banana peppers (and a little of the juice), fresh jalapeÃ±o (seeded), and canned roasted red peppers to the juice for the hour.  It was so good!

So I had never made Italian beef. This recipe was so easy  and came out delicious. After reading some review I did make changes. I didn't have onion powder or oregano or thyme. text:
So disappointed, even after following the recommendations from the highest rated, my first sample after 8hrs on low came out tasting dry and without much flavor.  I saved it by dumping out about 2/3 of the broth/liquid from cooking, added 2 more Italian seasoning packets and half a stick of butter to the remaining liquid. I shredded the cooked meat, disguarded the fat and returned meat to the liquid on warm in the crock pot until I served it to guests. By then it had a wonderful flavor.

text:
It was amazing! I did some modifications based on reviews and incorporated other recipe suggestions. I used one can of beef broth and half a can of water. Used onion powder instead of onion salt. Used 2 packets of Italian seasoning mix. I cut up two small onions and put at the bottom of crockpot. Cooked high for 5 hours then I took chuck roast out to shred. Added half a 16 oz jar of pepperoncinis without the juice and cooked it for an hour more. Buttered hoagie buns in over @ 400 for about 10 min then added beef and provolone onto the bun to cook for a few minutes in oven. Used sauce from crock pot of dipping

text:
These were awesome sandwiches and I got rave reviews! I followed the previous suggestions and used chuck roast, beef broth (rather than water), and doubled the amts of spices and salad dressing. I served grilled onions, mushrooms and peppers on the side, along with provolone cheese. Since I doubled the recipe for my crowd of 20,  and all 10 lbs wouldn't fit in my slow cooker, I cooked one 5 lb batch in the oven at 325 for approx 4 hours, and the other in crock pot. Placing both in the fridge overnight enabled me to skim off the fat the next day, then heat both together in the crock pot for the gathering. I barely had any left overs......unfortunately!!

text:
This made AWESOME sandwiches and was so easy. But with only the 2 of us, made it with a 2-1/2 roast and used 1tsp. of Italian seasoning instead of separate oregano and basil. Also used 1tsp. of garlic powder, not salt. Used beef broth, not plain water And used the whole .7ounce pkg. of Italian style dressing mix. It really wasn't too much. When the meat was tender, shredded it, returned it to the juices (as others suggested) plus add 1/2 sliced bell pepper. Piled the meat onto crispy rolls, added provolone cheese, placed under broiler till cheese melted. My husband and I loved this recipe, will definitely make again!!

userID:
5065009
Display Name:
Elijah Byrd
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderfully easy and tasty recipe. I took some advice from other reviewers and added two packets of Ranch dressing powder for every 5 lbs of beef (chuck roast, not rump), and I also added a few spoonfuls of granulated beef bouillon to the herb/water mix. I ended up with a gorgeous pot of roast that shredded beautifully - I just had to pull a few stubborn pieces of gristle from the pot, but I probably could have left them in if I was serving immediately. The leftovers stored very well, and have been used on sandwiches as well as in pasta and over rice. I'd recommend, for sandwiches, some smoked provolone and creamy horseradish, but hot mustard also works nicely.

If the fat bothers you, follow instructions in the other reviews to drain the liquid, refrigerate, and toss out the disk of fat that will form on top. The cooking liquid is full of flavor, so I'd highly recommend adding it back to the beef afterwards.

Next time I think I'll add in some hot peppers in the last couple hours of cooking. Will definitely be making again!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I've been making this recipe for our Christmas Eve hors d'ouevre/appetizer menu for years, and just for fun!! Only changes I make:    1)Chuck Roast (2.5-3 lbs)   2)Beef stock/broth instead of water.  3) rub beef with all seasonings, place beef in slow cooker, pour liquid around the beef & cook on low 8-12 hrs. Shred, return to pot for 1 hr. Absolutely delicious, serve on buns/ w optional toppings!

userID:

Display Name:
Malina Rome
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this several times and it is amazing!  I slice a red bell pepper into thin strips and a yellow onion and toss them into the pot on top of a large chuck roast. I sprinkle the roast with salt and pepper and give both sides of the roast a nice sear in my cast iron pan before adding to the crock pot.  When everything is all done I tale the meat out to shred it then I return it to the pot to soak up more flavor. I dip crusty hard rolls in the drippings, top with meat then a slice of provolone and stick the sandwich and top under the broiler open faced to toast. I do not alter the actual recipe as written because this is hands down THE BEST Italian beef sandwich I've ever eaten (better than any Chicago place even). My teen daughter literally giggles and claps excitedly like a small child when I am making this.  Thank you for sharing this, I don't know how we lived without this recipe all these years ;) For those who like to make a recipe their own by making changes,  DO NOT change this one it is one of those recipes that is perfect just as written.
Review:

5

city:

country:
None
text:
I followed what several reviewers recommended:  I left out the salt and onion salt, used 2 packages of Italian dressing, substituted onion powder for the onion salt, doubled all the spices, and used beef broth instead of water.  I also added sliced red, green, and yellow peppers the last hour of cooking.  It cooked for 9 hours, then I shredded the meat (removing the fat), and cooked for an additional 1 hour.   I served with toasted hoagie rolls, horseradish sauce, and giardiniera and topped it with provolone cheese.  I then baked the sandwiches at 400 degrees for 5 minutes.  This was very good!

userID:
871757
Display Name:
SANDIEGOCINDY
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1

55
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I highly recommend this recipe, especially for busy people. Easy to make in a crock pot while you are away from home. Here's my tweaks: I used a little over a 3# chuck roast. I used the same measurements as called for in the recipe (for a 5# roast), but used 2 packages of Zesty Italian Dressing (I buy the Kroger's brand because it's cheaper). I threw in a pinch of crushed red peppers and DELETED THE SALT and used Onion POWDER instead of Onion Salt (because I figured the ingredients have enough salt). Instead of water, use BEEF BROTH. Cook on low all day. When you get home from work, shred the beef and put back in the broth. At this point, I added a bit of Italian Seasoning, add a little bit of thin sliced onion and thin sliced green and red peppers along with a few sliced Peperoncinis. Let it cook a bit longer. So good on fresh toasted Italian Sandwich Rolls with some melted Provolone or Mozzarella Cheese. Also, recommend sauteeing some green and red pepper strips, sliced onions and sliced mushrooms and serve on top of the sandwiches. Reheats well for leftovers.

text:
5 stars for ease. and I love any recipe that uses the good old rump roast (vice the currently popular chuck)
I started with a scrawny 2.5 lb top round roast (sorta rump). used all the dry ingredients as listed in recipe. As for the wet stuff: didn't have dry Italian dressing so I added 1 cup of olive garden dressing from my fridge, this adds some vinegar and oil into the mix, 2 cups of beef broth, 1/2 cup of merlot. didn't boil anything tossed it all into the crock.  Set the roast into the mix, and topped it with minced garlic, salt, pepper. I'll cook my vege's (peppers, onion, garlic, and pepper flakes ) in a separate small qt sized crock 2 hrs before the meat is ready. tick tock...now I wait for the finished product.

text:
This was delicious. I made my own dry italian dressing mix (got it from Allrecipes). I also did not add salt and used low sodium chicken broth.  Cooked it for 3 hours on high then transferred it to my pressure cooker  for 40 min or it would not have been ready in time for dinner.  Shredded beautifully, very tender. Used fresh baked rolls and added a little parmesean cheese blend. So good. Will definitely make it again. My family loved it!

userID:
15838928
Display Name:
Lauren Klapp
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
13
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was so delicious! My husband said this is his new favorite dish.  I did make a few alterations. As others suggested; I used a chuck roast instead of rump roast and I did two packets of mix. I only used about 2.5 lbs of meat since it's only the two of us, but kept the ingredient amount the same. Instead of using water, I used 2 cups chicken broth (it's all I had) and 1 cup water. I'm going to try beef broth next time, but the chicken broth worked just fine. 

After about 8 hours; I shredded the beef, removed the big hunks of fat, and threw in an onion (cutting the onion into long strips) and cooked for an additional 2 hours. After the two hours I sauted some bell peppers, still letting the meat cook for about another 30 minutes or so, taking my time knowing that longer cooking time means tastier meat. Once the bell peppers were ready, I put the meat on a french roll along with the peppers (and a few fresh banana peppers) some sharp provolone cheese and broiled in the oven for about a minute, just to get the cheese melted. 

For anyone who tried the meat at 8 hours like I did, do not judge the meat yet. It was good, but I was unimpressed (and actually a little nervous it wouldnt be good) until after the shredded beef simmered for at least 2 more hours. I kept the slow cooker on "keep warm" and snacked on the meat the rest of the evening and it just got better and better. I didn't even use a fork at one point haha!

Display Name:
Joel'sGirl

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I think this has been reviewed enough times to make it clear what makes this recipe work: double the salad dressing mix (use the Italian salad dressing mix recipe on allrecipes!), and add a beef bouillon cube (I only use one- this can get really salty, really fast).  A couple more thoughts: I use onion and garlic powder (not onion salt or garlic salt), again because the salt can get to be a bit much.  The other big change I make is, I use a nice meaty soup bone in place of the roast.  I've never used anything but the soup bone so I can't make a comparison, but I can say that the soup bone yields a lovely, rich stock for this recipe.   I serve it on a crusty Italian bread or baguette, sometimes with spinach sautÃ©ed in garlic and oil, and always with hot peppers ("hoagie mix" or "hoagie spread" here in PA).  Makes for an excellent meal that freezes beautifully!  We have this once a week and look forward to it every time.

text:
I have made this and along with others substituted the beef broth instead of water but I used the low sodium beef broth. The beef turned out perfect and shredded very easily and  after shredding it left it in the juice for another hour. As far as the peppers, I cook them on the stove separately with olive oil, garlic powder, and oregano. I leave them covered and cook in their own juices and stir occasionally until they soften up and ready to put on the beef sandwich. The next time I make this will put them under the broiler with cheese to make cheesy beefs.

text:
My changes: 3 cups beef broth in place of water, 2 packets dry Italian dressing, and added some hot peppercini and some juice (didn't measure). I cooked on low 7 hours then turned crockpot to high, shredded meat, replaced meat in pot for an hour. THAT made all the difference in my humble opinion. Made this way (as well as suggested by prev reviews) gave the meat a fantastic flavor! I plated the beef topped with sautÃ©ed bell peppers & onions, and provolone. Definitely a keeper!!!

text:
Awesome flavor!  Go with what others have done.  Use beef broth instead of the water, and use double the Italian dressing.  I would also suggest cooking on low for at least 12 hours.  Other than that, it's a great meal.  I cut the string off the roast at the 10 hour mark, and it just fell apart.  It was so tender.  I let it cook another 2 hours after shredding to soak up more juice, and it was perfect.  Great meal!

text:
Definitely a keeper!  Will be doing this recipe again and again.  I used the beef broth and two packets of dressing mix as other reviews had suggested.  I also would highly recommend the longer cooking time on low.  I even turned my crock pot down to the "keep warm" setting for the last 3 hours or so.  The meat didn't even really need to be shredded, it fell apart when I pulled it out to shred it. We ate it on toasted buns with provolone melted on under the broiler.  Then added sauteed mushroom and onion with peppercinis on top.

country:
None
text:
I have made these several times for family and friends.  Each time I use two pot roasts just so we'll have enough!!  As per other comments I use, beef broth rather than water and an extra pkg. of Italian-style salad dressing.  I also saw a recipe in one of my cookbooks that was very similar to this one that said to put in a package of brown gravy, so I do that also.  Very good!!  I butter and toast the rolls, then top them with the meat and  provolone cheese and put them under the broiler for just a minute to melt the cheese and put the extra gravy in a serving pitcher on the side.  This is an easy dish to make and always a hit!  Thank you, Maureen!!

As a Texas expatriate in Chicagoland, I fell in love with Italian beef sandwiches the moment I tried them.  This recipe creates a wonderful home-made version.  One caveat for my Texas (and other non-Illinois) brethren:  Real Italian beef is sliced deli-style.  Not really something you can accomplish with slow-cooker beef.  This recipe is still awesome.

This recipe is fabulous!  I did use beef broth instead of water like some of the other reviewers recommended.  I also took meat out after 10 hours of slow cooking and I strained the broth and skimmed some of the fat.  I shredded the meat and added some broth back in.  I kept the rest in a bowl on the side for anyone who wanted au jus. I'm going to use a larger roast next time and make this for a crowd.  It's like eating great pot roast sandwiches.  A keeper.

userID:
845074
Display Name:
Dahling 2
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
7
favoritesCount:
45
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As if this needs anymore stars! Wanted something a little different for post football game meal. Found this recipe and am I glad I did! Used a 5.65 lb. sirloin tip, upped all the spices, used 3 pkg of the Italian salad dressing mix, threw in some strips of onion and four cloves of fresh garlic. Used all beef broth and cooked about 10 hrs on low. Removed the roast from broth and let rest then sliced with my electric knife. Limited resources as far as bread so I had to use French, which I split and toasted in the oven. Topped with provolone and put under the broiler to melt. The giardiniara is key!!! Couldn't do the hot because of some guests' "wimpy" paletes so I used regular and added sliced pepperoncini. This was amazing! Limited myself to one small 4 " sandwich but could totally have gone crazy and eaten a larger one. This recipe is a keeper!!!
Review:
Rating:
5

2010-09-10T12:26:55.953

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had an eight pound found tip roast from Costco that I wasn't sure what to do with.  Tried this recipe and the results were amazing.  The only thing different I did was brown the roast first, then put it in the crockpot  using 4cups of water and two packages of Italian seasoning mix along with the other ingredients.  I cooked it on high for five hours, then turned it on low for four.  The outside of the roast was falling apart, and that's what we ate on sandwich rolls with grilled onions, green peppers and provolone cheese.  I then put the remainder of the roast back in the crockpot and cooked on low overnight.  I turned it off in the morning, and the entire roast was just falling apart.  Wonderful  aromas through the house and just delicious.  My picky husband even said it was excellent.  Will have this again, and again.  So easy and  versatile.
Review:

text:
Delicious!  I used other reviewer suggestions and bought a 2.5 lb rump roast and used 2 packs of Italian dressing.  It was the perfect amount with the juice.  I also used beef *stock* instead of water and added a sliced onion.  I cooked mine on low for 4 hours; sliced it and cooked it for another hour; then I shredded it, added the onion and cooked it for an additional hour before I switched it to "warm".  Very good recipe.  A must try.

I prepared this in advance of some out of state relatives coming to visit.  It was a HIT!  They gobbled up all of it in two days as lunch or late evening snacks. I'll prepare this regularly.  Note: I did use low-sodium beef broth in place of water and tossed in a seeded, chopped jalapeno into the seasoning mix for a hint of heat.

text:
I really love this recipe, and my husband did too! He is hispanic and has never had something like this but in the end he polished off the whole pot in two days! I used a 5 lb rump roast, 3.5 cups of beef broth, 2 french dressing packets, all the spices as is, for 12ish hours on slow. About 2 hours before end time, i added a dash of all the seasoning again. I removed the meat to shred it and remove the fat. Let meat simmer for two more hours. Served with wheat french bread, grilled onions, red and green bell pepper.

text:
Ok, so I'm lazy. It's summer and I didn't want to haul out the crockpot nor heat up the kitchen with the oven. So I went to the grocery and got Boarshead filet of beef thinly sliced from the deli. I used 1 pound, 1 carton of beef stock and the spices as listed in the recipe PLUS three cloves of crushed garlic. Simmered it on my stove top for about 30 min then served on toasted rolls. DELICIOUS. Next time I plan to double the Italian packet and simmer longer for even more flavor. But it is VERY similar to the beef sandwiches I had as a kid in Chicago. Throw on some of that giardirian (or whatever it's called), dip it in shallow dish of the au jus....YUM!

KDags

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/2352.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very delicious! I used a 2.5 lb roast, but did not cut any other ingredients. In fact, after making round 1 of sandwiches, I actually added more water and Italian seasonings (but not the dressing mix) to the remaining beef and left on the warm cycle until it was time for "seconds" - and those were even better. I give 4 stars instead of 5 because I'm sure if I'd had a 5lb roast and was serving a lot of people I would have run out of au jus, which is a critical part of the deliciousness of this sandwich. Instead of the individual oregeno, parsley, and basil I used 3 tsp Italian seasoning mix. I was also out of onion powder, and don't have onion salt, so that portion was omitted. I used a Kosher flaked salt so I used a full tsp, but for regular table salt would have gone with a 1/2 tsp.   I cooked on high for about 3 hours, then sliced meat thinly and returned to juice on high for 1 hour. Then I shredded the meat and kept on warm for another hour before the first serving. I served on French bread with white American cheese.

text:
I am not one to normally leave reviews, but this was one outstanding meal. Extremely easy and crazy flavorful. I took suggestions from others and replaced the water with beef broth and the onion salt with onion powder. The meat still came out quite salty, but it was not overpowering enough to knock out the other flavors. At the 8 hour mark, I shredded the meat and then let it cook for another 2 hours. After 10 hours of soaking, the meat melted like butter. The ladyfriend was speechless at how fantastic it turned out. Cannot wait to make this one again.

Display Name:
freezermama
